out_tit_tool: Phonological Awareness (Post test Means/SDs) - Joint Reading vs Control
out_desc_tool: Two tasks developed for the present study served as measures of phonological awareness  one referring to alliteration and the other to rhymes. Each included 10 two-syllable word pairs. On the alliteration task, we asked children if the first syllable of a word resembled or differed from the first syllable of its paired word. On the rhyming task, we asked the same question with reference to word pairs’ final syllables.

out_desc_tool: The Peabody Picture Vocabulary Test (PPVT) was used to examine children’s receptive vocabulary, using Solberg and Nevo's (1979) translation to a Hebrew items set. The interviewer asked the child to choose one picture out of four, depicting a spoken word. Inasmuch as only preliminary Hebrew norms were available for children older than the present sample, raw scores were used. The receptive vocabulary score amounted to the number of correct responses.

out_desc_tool: Prompted Recall Measure of Main Idea. The posttest book was also a book that had not been read to the children previously, entitled, From Tadpole to Frog. Immediately following the reading, the child was asked to provide a free recall of the book  “I want you to tell me everything you remember about the story. Tell me the story”. The researcher wrote down the child’s response verbatim. When the child appeared to be finished with their free recall, they were given a single, “Anything else?” prompt, and the researcher wrote down any additional comments from the child. A rubric was developed by the author in collaboration with a colleague to score the recalls. There were 46 total possible points for this test.
out_desc_red: NA

out_tit_tool: California Achievement Test(Reading comprehension)-Success approach-Success in Kindergarten Reading and Writing (1980)
out_desc_tool: The purpose of the California Achievement Test is to measure the student's achievement in the areas of reading and language. It was administered in March 1987 to all subjects of the investigation. The Reading and Language subtests measure a student's ability in the areas of Reading Comprehension, Reading Vocabulary, Total Reading, Language Expression, Visual Recognition, and Sound Recognition. Measures of achievement on the subtests and scores are indicated by percentiles, stanines, and standard scores. Procedures for administering the instruments were those as outlined in the Examiner's Manual.

out_desc_tool: The Expressive Vocabulary Test (EVT) is a measure for expressive vocabulary and has been co-normed with the PPVT-test. The scores of an individual can be compared on both these tests  a measure of word retrieval can be derived and interpreted. It contains 190 items, the first are 38 labeling items, and the rest are synonym items in which the examiner presents a picture and a word and the examinee responds with a synnonym. The EVT compares the fiction and non-fiction intervention groups to control (using Table 4).

The print concepts section is an evaluation of the child's understanding of the reading process that covers what one reads, why one reads, and how one reads.

out_tit_tool: 24-item vocabulary posttest scores -storybook readings with explicit instruction
out_desc_tool: The vocabulary posttest was designed to assess the receptive vocabulary knowledge of 24 target vocabulary words that were presented in the storybooks for the first experimental group. The classroom teachers who implemented the lessons administered the tests to each participant. The test was administered during the conclusion of the four-week research period. The test consisted of 24 forced-choice items and the administration time ranged between 3-5 minutes. Each question was read orally to the students and two possible answer choices were provided. The examiner read the testing prompt followed by the 24 test items  “We will play a question and answer game. I will ask you a question and you will give me an answer. I will give you two answer choices. If you do not know the answer, you may say, I do not know. Question  Which would be unattractive? Answer choices  Getting a shot from the doctor? or Going shopping at the toy store?” The vocabulary posttest measure used in this study is located in Appendix C.

out_tit_tool: Vocabulary Growth test score(taught vocabulary)-oral language
out_desc_tool: At pre- and posttest, all participants were administered a measure assessing selected vocabulary from the stories used in storybook intervention. The National Reading Panel (2000) concluded that specific vocabulary growth is best assessed through researcher- developed measures because these measures are more sensitive to gains achieved through instruction than are standardized tools. To assess specific vocabulary growth, we developed a 20-word instrument in which students were asked to produce word meanings or tell anything they knew about target words. Ten specific words were randomly selected from the pool of explicitly taught vocabulary, and the remaining 10 words were randomly selected from the pool of words that appeared in the stories but received no explicit instructional emphasis. No more than one word per story occurred in the measure. The measure was individually administered at pre- and postintervention in two separate sessions of 10 words each. Each assessment item consisted of two questions  (a) asking the definition of the word (e.g., “What is a principal?” “What does roared mean?”), and (b) asking a what, when, or how question (e.g., “What does a principal do?” “What do you do when you roar?”). To guide scoring, definitions for each word were specified, including dictionary definitions, synonyms, and the informal definition used during storybook instruction. A panel of four scorers further determined the criteria, awarding points to responses that did not match the listed definitions or synonyms. Student responses were scored on a scale of 0 to 3 points per word. A score of 3 was awarded to responses matching the listed definitions or synonyms  responses that had no relation to the listed definitions received 0 points. A separate total score was calculated for each student for taught words and untaught words. Total possible scores on each of the assessments ranged from 0 to 30 points. Interscorer reliability calculated on 10% of the words was above 90%.

To guide scoring, definitions for each word were specified, including dictionary definitions, synonyms, and the informal definition used during storybook instruction. A panel of four scorers further determined the criteria, awarding points to responses that did not match the listed definitions or synonyms. Student responses were scored on a scale of 0 to 3 points per word. A separate total score was calculated for each student for taught words and untaught words. Total possible scores on each of the assessments ranged from 0 to 30 points. Interscorer reliability calculated on 10% of the words was above 90%.

out_tit_tool: Listening comprehension-direct and extended vocabulary instruction
out_desc_tool: We used an adapted version of the SNAP (Strong, 1998) to assess students’ listening comprehension. In the SNAP, students listen to a story read aloud while following along with pictures in a wordless storybook. We adapted the SNAP by incorporating 18 of our target words into the story, which had 395 total words. We selected target words that were representative of the words taught throughout the intervention and could be integrated in the story. Each of the words that were incorporated into the SNAP was also assessed as part of the target word measure. Following the reading, students were asked 10 questions about the story that were both literal and inferential. We adapted 5 of the questions so that they included a target word in the question (e.g., What happened when Joe grasped at the frog?) Answers to questions were scored as either correct or incorrect. The internal consistency reliability for this measure was .69.

The internal consistency reliability for this measure was .69.

out_desc_tool: Peabody Picture Vocabulary Test-Ill [PPVT-III] post test means and SDs extracted for ES calculation.   The PPVT-III is an untimed, individually administered, standardized, norm-referenced measure. The PPVT was administered at pre- and posttest to assess general, receptive vocabulary knowledge. Examiners ask respondents to point to a picture representing an orally stated vocabulary word on a plate of four pictures  the three remaining pictures are distractors. The PPVT-III is arranged in order of increasing vocabulary difficulty, and the average testing time takes between 11 and 12 minutes.

out_desc_tool: Part 1  Listening comprehension with no suitable test for kindergarten-aged childrenavailable in Arabic, one was constructed modeledafter those used in studies of Hebrew-speaking kindergartners(Eshel, 1991). The test contained four shortpassages in FusHa, each ending with a question andfour multiple choice answers, and one long passagewith three questions. Each correct answer received ascore of 1. A score of 7 was therefore the highest a childcould obtain. Test-retest reliability, established in twokindergarten classes in another town, was r = .76. Asthis was close to the value of .80 recommended byNunnally (1978) for research purposes, reliability wasjudged to be satisfactory.

out_desc_tool: The third edition of the Expressive One-Word Picture Vocabulary Test (EOWPVT-III) developed by Brownell (2000) was used to assess kindergarteners’ vocabulary before and after the read-aloud sessions. Three previously trained graduate students administered the pre- and posttests. The EOWPVT-III requires children to name a picture and yields standardized scores of expressive vocabulary—the words, according to Brownell that “an individual uses when they speak or write” (p. 11). This test requires no reading or writing ability and is a reliable assessment of children’s language development.
out_desc_red: Comprehension questions focusing upon plot information, inferences, and general knowledge about story grammar were asked prior, during, and after reading (Reese & Cox, 1999). Assessment sessions were audiotaped and later transcribed for scoring, with students receiving 1 point for each correct answer (following the scoring procedure used by Reese and Cox for comprehension questions), 1/2 point for answers that were partially correct, and 0 points for incorrect answers. – (An extreme effect size! Code as secondary outcome)

out_desc_red: In addition, children were also administered a test of new words introduced in the ten books read at day-care.The test, labeled Book Vocabulary, required children to label 18 nouns from color photocopies of pictures taken from the books. The items were  antlers, bat, clover,colt, croquet, fountain, hedgehogs, lighthouse, llama, mallet, moose, otter, owl, plane (the tool), possum, rocket, tiger, and violin.

out_desc_tool: The PPVT-III is a test of listening comprehension for the spoken word in Standard English (Dunn & Dunn, 1997). The purpose of the test is two-fold. First, the test is designed to measure an examinee’s receptive (hearing) vocabulary, and as such, is an achievement test measuring vocabulary acquisition. Second, the PPVT-III serves as a screening test of verbal ability when English is the language of the examinee’s home, community, and school.

First, the test is designed to measure an examinee’s receptive (hearing) vocabulary, and as such, is an achievement test measuring vocabulary acquisition. Second, the PPVT-III serves as a screening test of verbal ability when English is the language of the examinee’s home, community, and school.

out_desc_tool: Number of C-Units (Utterances and Responses)  Transcripts of Story 1 in Session 2 and Story 5 in Session 4 were made by a transcriber from the audiotapes for each child. The transcript included all talking by the adult and child for the two stories Responses were those utterances which immediately followed an adult target question or comment. Each utterance by the child might consist of a single utterance or a series of utterances, but each series of utterances was coded with a single code of spontaneous utterance or response. The spontaneous comments were analyzed for the number of communication units (c-units) they contained. A c-unit is an independent clause along with any dependent clauses it contains (Loban, 1976). The c-unit system is identical to the t-unit system (Hunt , 1965), but it also accounts for some spoken language characteristics such as elliptical utterances. The children's comments were measured in c-units to account for any variation in complexity of comments. A child might provide a simple acknowledgment on one occasion and several well formed sentences on another. By using a c-unit analysis, children were credited for the complexity of their comments.
out_desc_red: NA

out_desc_tool: Children were asked for the meanings of the 12 words from the book’s text which appeared in the dictionary mode of the e-book activity. As described above, these words were judged to be relatively difficult for children of this age and were the most difficult words in the book. Each word was orally presented to the children and three optional meanings were suggested. The children were asked to choose the best meaning. For example, the children were asked  ‘What is the meaning of the word “container” (in Hebrew meihal)? (a) Is it a big truck? (b) Is it a big bottle? or (c) Is it a mail box?’ Before they were tested, to prepare them for the task, the children were given two examples in which the researchers provided the answer.

out_tit_tool: Language ability, print concept knowledge, and letter knowledge
out_desc_tool: All children were individually assessed on two measures  The Test of Early Language Development (TELD) (Hresko, Reid, & Hammill, 1981) and an emergent literacy criterion measure, drawing on the Beginning Educational Assessment (BEA) (Mason & Stewart, 1990), which assessed print concept development, letter knowledge development, and reading and writing development. Combination of standardised and researcher developed tests.
out_tit_red: Language ability, print concept knowledge, and letter knowledge

The TERA consists of a series of items which are specifically designed to measure the student's awareness of print in environmental contexts, vocabulary, listening comprehension, knowledge of the alphabet, and concepts about printed language.

out_desc_tool: The California Achievement Test. The CAT (1985), a standardized instrument, is administered by the district each April. out_desc_tool: Children’s total number of comment and question responses.Scoring. The coding system for describing children’s responses to interactive storybook readings was devised from other studies that categorized children's responses to storybook readings and from an analysis of tapes from the previous investigation of one-to-one story readings. Taxonomies for traditional comprehension categories and story structure elements were also reviewed Categories, then, were based on the literature studied and my own data An effort vas made to limit categories and to provide a cod .'.g system that could be used easily for instructional, diagnostic, and research purposes The major categories were  (a) focus on story structure, (b) focus on meaning, and (c) focus on print and illustrations (Cochran-Smith, i984  Heath, 1982  Morrow. 1985  1987  Nimo& Bruner. 1978.Roser& Martinez. 1985, Sulzby. Yaden, 1985  Yaden & McGee, 1984). Transcribed tape.-, of story sessions were analyzed by research assistants blind to the group assignments of children Children’s questions and comments were counted and categorized into the major categories, and then into appropriate subcategories

out_desc_tool: The researchers used the PPVT-III, Forms A and B (Dunn & Dunn, 1997), as a general measure of receptive vocabulary. The PPVT-III is recommended for use in educational and clinical settings to measure receptive vocabulary and to screen for English language ability and general language development. On the PPVT-III, the child points to one of four pictures on a panel that represents an object or action that the examiner names.

out_tit_tool: The Peabody Picture Vocabulary Test score-oral language
out_desc_tool: The Peabody Picture Vocabulary Test is an untimed individual test designed to provide an estimate of the subject's verbal intelligence through his hearing vocabu­ lary. This instrument was developed by Lloyd M. Dunn of the George Peabody College for Teachers, Nashville, Tennessee. This instrument consists of three practice and ISO test plates, each of which contains four numbered pictures. Alternate forms are available by using the same plates, but designating a different stimulus word for Form A and Form B. The examiner says the stimulus word and the subject responds by indicating orally or by pointing to the picture which best illustrates the word. Items are arranged in ascending order. The subject's basal response is de­ termined by giving the correct response to eight consecutive stimulus words. The subject's ceiling is reached when he experiences six failures out of eight consecutive responses. The directions for administering the test suggest appro­ priate starting points for different ages. The subject's score is determined by subtracting the number of incorrect responses from his ceiling response score. The subject's score can be converted into three types of derived scores  percentile rank, mental age, or standard score deviation IQ with a means of 100 and a standard deviation of fifteen.
out_desc_red: NA

out_desc_tool: Composite score- Software with enhancement for improving discourse skills. Preschool Language Assessment Instrument (PLAI), a test based on a model of classroom discourse, which has four separate subtests or levels. A raw score, which is computed for each of the four levels, can be converted into a mean score for each level. On the PLAI, questions from all four levels are randomly spaced throughout the test. The test items are specific to problem solving situations, often with pictures, that were developed for this test. The composite score were sums PLAI subtests.
out_desc_red: NA

out_desc_tool: The receptive vocabulary test was constructed as in Senechal & Cornell (1993). The procedure and the format of the material used for the receptive vocabulary test were similar to those used in the Peabody Picture Vocabulary Test-Revised (PPVT-R  Dunn & Dunn, 1981). That is, the test consisted of one plate for each target item. Each plate consisted of four illustrations, one representing the target item and three representing foils. The foils also represented items pictured in the book. For example, the plate for the label infant included a baby, a young girl, a woman and an elderly lady which were all represented in the book. The procedure for the receptive vocabulary tests was the same as the PPVT–R, that is, children were asked to point to a named item. If children hesitated to respond or said that they did not know the word, the experimenter said that some of the words were hard but to try just the same. The experimenter did not proceed to the next plate until children made a selection. If children changed their selection, the experimenter recorded the children’s last choice. Children were familiarized with the testing procedure with three plates representing familiar items.

out_tit_tool: Mean Number of New Words Correctly Produced (New Word Production Test (NWPT) test score-oral language
out_desc_tool: The New Word Production Test (NWPT) assessed children’s ability to produce the nine target words contained in the storybooks (i.e., expressive vocabulary knowledge). Children were shown a picture and asked to label it. Pictures of target items were interspersed with pictures of highly familiar items. Presentation of the pictures, both target items and non-target items, were randomized. Children earned one point for each correct response to a target item.

Children were shown a picture and asked to label it. Pictures of target items were interspersed with pictures of highly familiar items. Presentation of the pictures, both target items and non-target items, were randomized. Children earned one point for each correct response to a target item.

out_desc_tool: This test assessed children's comprehension of the nine target words contained in the storybooks. In other words, this was a measure of receptive vocabulary knowledge of the target words. Word presentation followed the same procedure as that used in the PPVT-III to test general vocabulary knowledge. Children heard a word and selected one of four pictures as a match.
